clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! Here’s your #crypticclueaday:

Burn is Mother’s attractive quality (8)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Hi folks, I’m having surgery very early tomorrow morning, so #explanationfriday starts now. CHARISMA (“attractive quality”) is CHAR (“burn”) plus IS (given in the clue) plus MA (“Mother”). https://t.co/1tA3nJrXHP

clue_tweet_text:
Plant sauce (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text:
In this double definition, MOLE is a “plant” (as in a spy) and a “sauce” (in its two syllable form). 

#explanationfriday https://t.co/h2rlc4UiMB

clue_tweet_text:
Newsworthy winner tricks heir deviously (4,6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text:
RICH STRIKE is the “newsworthy winner” (of the Kentucky Derby) that you get from anagramming (“deviously”) TRICKS HEIR.

#explanationfriday https://t.co/3qO9dmuTz9

clue_tweet_text:
Mythical creature to take forever (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text:
DRAGON is a “mythical creature” you get from DRAG ON (“to take forever”). 

#explanationfriday https://t.co/BuStNtxaTu

clue_tweet_text:
Florence West’s movement (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text:
Add FLO (“Florence”) to W (“West”) to get FLOW (“movement”).

#explanationfriday https://t.co/hMweADFUmb

clue_tweet_text:
Drunken pal loses the fifth (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text:
Remove the fifth letter (“loses the fifth”) from FRIEND to get FRIED, or “drunken.”

#explanationfriday https://t.co/0HQo9URGbC

clue_tweet_text:
Actress rearranged petunia plot (5,6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text:
“Rearrange,” or anagram, PETUNIA PLOT to get PATTI LUPONE, an “actress.”

#explanationfriday https://t.co/RoR450D0HA

clue_tweet_text:
At the crack of ass, in the manner of a part of the head? (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: EARLY (“at the crack of ass,” which is when I had to get up for my surgery last week) is EAR-LY, or “in the manner of a part of the head?” The question mark indicates non-literal wordplay. #explanationfriday https://t.co/I0MXxbF7gB

clue_tweet_text:
Rude dude’s body odor, or…? (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: BOOR (“rude dude” is BO (“body odor”) plus OR (given in the clue). #explanationfriday https://t.co/Zl85cYvotj

clue_tweet_text:
Wager nothing for Texas gubernatorial candidate (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: BETO (“Texas gubernatorial candidate”) is BET (“wager”) plus O (“nothing,” as in zero). #explanationfriday https://t.co/cgVUCwXJHd

clue_tweet_text:
Elude a general explosion in addictive online pastime (13)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“explosion”) ELUDE A GENERAL to get LEARNEDLEAGUE, an “addictive online pastime.” @LearnedLeague #explanationfriday https://t.co/CgXdqAkoPH

clue_tweet_text:
Possesses that guy’s hospital drug (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: HASHISH (“drug”) is HAS (“possesses”) plus HIS (“that guy’s”) plus H (“hospital”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/kUrJCXaPlS

clue_tweet_text:
Announced lowland ski resort (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: VAIL is the “ski resort” that’s a homophone (“announced”) of VALE (“lowland”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/hVqM6Rb1o3

clue_tweet_text:
Flashy, filled with neutral decoration (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: GARNISH (“decoration”) is GARISH (“flashy”) “filled with” the letter N (“neutral”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/FyaB6oVjMo

clue_tweet_text:
Another #explanationfriday in the books! Here’s your #crypticclueaday:

Give the wrong wig to S&M practitioner? (8)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: A MISTRESS is the “S&M practitioner” you get from MIS-TRESS (“give the wrong wig to”). The question mark indicates that the wordplay is not fully literal. #explanationfriday https://t.co/Anookh1EJQ

clue_tweet_text:
Between Utah and California, one city (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Put I (“one”) “between” UT and CA (the postal abbreviations for Utah and California) to get the “city” of UTICA. #explanationfriday https://t.co/VIJvkzlzql

clue_tweet_text:
Not for polite company, like data transmission rates on the radio? (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: BAWDY (“not for polite company”) is a homophone (“on the radio”) of BAUD-Y (“like data transmission rates”). Once again, the question mark indicates not-quite-literal wordplay. #explanationfriday https://t.co/q6O2M6WsJn

clue_tweet_text:
Demoralize relative after drive (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Place AUNT, a “relative,” after the letter D (“drive” as in the car gear) to get DAUNT (“demoralize”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/42GOAzKqx1

clue_tweet_text:
Bonus #crypticclueaday, foreign-language pop culture edition:

Drag Race España star “Butt Sex Royalty” embraces part of California (3,7)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Couldn’t resist cluing ANA LOCKING (“Drag Race España star”) as ANAL KING (“butt sex royalty”) “embracing” OC (“part of California,” i.e., Orange County). #explanationfriday https://t.co/uyl2LQxg00

clue_tweet_text:
App in which successful runners make graffiti hit (9)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: INS (“successful runners,” as in elected politicians”) plus TAG (“make graffiti”) plus RAM (“hit”) makes INSTAGRAM (“app”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/UwggvaYETc

clue_tweet_text:
Scare farm animal (3)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: In this double definition, COW means both “scare” and “farm animal.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/cBBSAyQ3Y5

clue_tweet_text:
Oil, say, that lady’s dad (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: FAT (“oil, say”) plus HER (“that lady’s”) gives you FATHER (“dad”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/qfHDNa4J0Y

clue_tweet_text:
Hope you enjoyed #explanationfriday. Here’s your #crypticclueaday:

NBA star with no time doubled up for band (5,5)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Take DURANT (“NBA star”), remove the T (“no time”), and “double up” the result to get a “band”—DURAN DURAN. #explanationfriday https://t.co/pvptOEBuzz

clue_tweet_text:
Officer’s phrase about the ladies? (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: A SHE-RIFF is a “phrase about the ladies?” (The question mark indicates that the wordplay isn’t quite literal.) That gets you SHERIFF, an “officer.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/fMF7e9SDWV

clue_tweet_text:
Country of the Spanish invasion of body of water (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: If you “invade” POND, a “body of water,” with LA (“the Spanish,” or “the” in Spanish), you get the “country” of POLAND. #explanationfriday https://t.co/qXBrBCeAOP

clue_tweet_text:
Mailed mayor constituents right now (8,3)

#crypticclueaday Like if you've got it.
explanation_tweet_text: When this clue was posted, “right now” was MEMORIAL DAY, which can be made from the “constituents” (i.e., anagrammed) of MAILED MAYOR. #explanationfriday https://t.co/Nt7nDMu1hg

clue_tweet_text:
English philosopher is crooked, bad actor (7) 

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Jeremy BENTHAM is the “English philosopher” you get from BENT (“crooked”) plus HAM (“bad actor”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/v2hsCVfwUR

clue_tweet_text:
Cartoon baby, denied opening, becomes collegian in Texas (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Deny the opening”—that is, remove the first letter from—MAGGIE, a “cartoon baby,” to get AGGIE, a “collegian in Texas.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/HQLX5V0d23

clue_tweet_text:
Generate small chess piece (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Easiest of the week: SPAWN, or “generate,” is S (“small”) plus PAWN (“chess piece”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/tQrXmBj4py

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday. Now for your #crypticclueaday:

Actor Scott seizes railroad neighborhood (6)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: It’s #explanationfriday again! BARRIO is the “neighborhood” you get when BAIO (“actor Scott”) “seizes” RR, the abbreviation for “railroad.” https://t.co/SkMwP07Az0

clue_tweet_text:
Thrive like a staple? (8)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: FLOUR is “a staple,” so “like a staple,” not literally (hence the question mark) is FLOUR-ISH, or FLOURISH (“thrive”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/MRVXFOvaIT

clue_tweet_text:
#150 unit is secure (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: CL is 150 in Roman numerals; add INCH, a “unit,” to get CLINCH, or “secure” (in the verb sense). #explanationfriday https://t.co/vL0gGx7ppg

clue_tweet_text:
Bar bill with rounds is verboten (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Add TAB (“bar bill”) to two letter Os (“rounds,” get it?) to get TABOO (“verboten”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/XzDDjusroW

clue_tweet_text:
Singer’s unhappy energy (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: SADE is the “singer” you get from SAD (“unhappy”) plus E, an abbreviation for “energy.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/p529K28nSg

clue_tweet_text:
Double praise, in retrospect (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Reverse (“in retrospect”) the word LAUD (“praise”) to get DUAL (“double”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/ZiLJIRDi54

clue_tweet_text:
Elephant omen masks spirit (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: PHANTOM is the “spirit” that’s “masked” by, or hidden in, the phrase “elePHANT OMen.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/hjppZZQ074

clue_tweet_text:
Hope you enjoyed #explanationfriday. And now your #crypticclueaday:

Boozy card game (5)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: It’s time I explained a few things! RUMMY is both “boozy” and a “card game.” The etymology of the latter appears to be unknown but possibly from the liquor; I decided “unknown” was good enough to call it not an etymological dupe. #explanationfriday https://t.co/yLET87WfWF

clue_tweet_text:
A rakish, unusual Colombian (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: SHAKIRA is the “Colombian” you get from anagramming (“unusual”) A RAKISH. #explanationfriday https://t.co/CY8vXHhqav

clue_tweet_text:
Lady takes possession of California road construction material (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: MACADAM is the “road construction material” you get when MADAM (“lady”) “takes possession of” the letters CA (“California”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/wwKN5YGCA0

clue_tweet_text:
Take both sides of dudes’ facial hair (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: BEAR (“take,” in its “abide” sense) plus “both sides of”—that is, the first and last letters of—DUDES gives you BEARDS (“facial hair”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/KWR50n9vcY

clue_tweet_text:
Part of the leg is not feeling well, beset by pains (8) 

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: ACHILLES is the “part of the leg” you get when ILL (“not feeling well”) is “beset by,” or put inside, the word ACHES (“pains”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/KYGUe9a4T9

clue_tweet_text:
Messy eaters’ holiday (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: EASTER is the “holiday” you get from anagramming (“messy”) EATERS. #explanationfriday https://t.co/3MfxDgPMQN

clue_tweet_text:
Tell stories about storm (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: REGALE (“tell stories”) is RE (“about,” as in the subject line of a memo sense) plus GALE (“storm”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/2l1OOR3NCI

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! Now your #crypticclueaday, which was inspired by a typo on a chalkboard sign in Brooklyn.

Beer, swallowed right, becomes bigger (6)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: The typo was LARGER (“bigger”), which is LAGER (“beer,” the word that was meant on the sign in question) “swallowing” the letter R (“right”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/Pl6pZVipx6

clue_tweet_text:
South Carolina superhero: The Hyena, say (9)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: SCAVENGER (“the hyena, say”; ignore the deceptive capitalization) is SC (“South Carolina”) plus AVENGER (“superhero”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/Q8tOjpqP8D

clue_tweet_text:
Bird eating bit of nut is ready to use right away (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Tough one! TURNKEY (“ready to use right away,” in a real-estate sense) is TURKEY (“bird”) “eating” the letter N. “Bit of” is a common indicator phrase meaning “take the first letter of the word that follows” (NUT, in this case). #explanationfriday https://t.co/EI7v5Py8zm

clue_tweet_text:
Part of the head’s sacred space (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: In this double definition, the word TEMPLE is both “part of the head” and a “sacred space.” Yes, they have different etymologies! #explanationfriday https://t.co/qAUHcdgCwd

clue_tweet_text:
Foodie is inside, testing our metalware (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: GOURMET is the “foodie” found “inside” the phrase “testinG OUR METalware.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/ihaCtaNVFe

clue_tweet_text:
In confusion, ask peer for stereo component (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“in confusion”) ASK PEER to get SPEAKER, a “stereo component.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/k7bfejIKof

clue_tweet_text:
Nice, the French device (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: KINDLE (“device”) is KIND (“nice”) plus LE (“the French,” or “the” in French). #explanationfriday https://t.co/boJZVW3RWn

clue_tweet_text:
Another #explanationfriday in the books! Here’s your #crypticclueaday:

Go fishing for percussion instrument? (8)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Happy Canada Day to those who celebrate! And happy #explanationfriday as well: CAST A NET (“go fishing”) gives you CASTANET, a “percussion instrument.” Question mark indicates the not-100%-literal wordplay. https://t.co/FGs87rICh3

clue_tweet_text:
Extreme hotel and places to stay outdoors announced (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you've got it.
explanation_tweet_text: INTENSE (“extreme”) is a homophone (“announced”) of INN TENTS (“hotel and places to stay”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/AONmxjbPPx

clue_tweet_text:
Two guys come together in the city I’m visiting right now (7) 🇨🇦 

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: At the time I wrote this clue, “the city I’m visiting right now” was CALGARY, which splits into two men’s names, CAL and GARY (“two guys come together”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/VhVVLHZbQD

clue_tweet_text:
Oh, look, darling! Beginners just like me (3)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it. https://t.co/aoNe1yZ5bV
explanation_tweet_text: OLD (“just like me”) is made from the “beginners,” or first letters, of each of the first three words in the clue. #explanationfriday https://t.co/66Ygo6jCe7

clue_tweet_text:
Tsunami on broken peaks (9)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: When the phrase TSUNAMI ON is “broken,” or anagrammed, you get MOUNTAINS (“peaks”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/hCIw8W0mnC https://t.co/Mexp7wW4Ga

clue_tweet_text:
Composer consumed by liver disease (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: VERDI is the “composer” hidden in, or “consumed by,” the phrase “liVER DIsease.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/CwX3bzbnSu

clue_tweet_text:
“Hey, Ken—back off, tramp” (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: This clue was not a dig at @ckstern! You get HIKE (“tramp”) from HI (“hey”) plus KEN with the “back off”—i.e., remove the last letter. #explanationfriday https://t.co/T6J4osc0Uu

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! One more timely #crypticclueaday:

Compare, at first, two articles by district attorney: “True North,” “Strong and Free” (6)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Happy #explanationfriday! CANADA, per its national anthem, is “true North, strong and free,” and is also C (“compare, at first,” or the first letter of COMPARE) plus the indefinite articles AN and A, plus DA (“district attorney”). https://t.co/mdOUc0gwGt

clue_tweet_text:
Peeled citrus fruit for a really nice person (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Peel,” or remove the outer letters from, TANGELO to get ANGEL, a “really nice person.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/NZaI4EtSbA

clue_tweet_text:
Put Mr. Jackson in control of a trial, often (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: PLACE (“put”) plus BO (“Mr. Jackson”) gives you PLACEBO (“control of a trial, often”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/vS3i1Rtb66

clue_tweet_text:
Composer is, to a great extent, America (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: SOUSA (“composer”) is SO (“to a great extent”) plus USA (“America”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/6W0NctL0XN

clue_tweet_text:
The reverend said sexual content publicity makes a lively dance (8)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Any time you see “the reverend,” a spoonerism is involved: spoonerize PORN HYPE (“sexual content publicity”) to get HORNPIPE, a “lively dance.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/lMQsqwG2yv

clue_tweet_text:
Some paper from edited theses (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: When the word THESES is “edited,” or anagrammed, you get SHEETS (“some paper”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/3Gb1DjSqua

clue_tweet_text:
Small jerk’s impertinence (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: SASS (“impertinence”) is S (an abbreviation for “small”) plus ASS (“jerk”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/P7mmFcGppD

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday!

Tree and sheep in retreat (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Whew! It’s #explanationfriday! An ASH is a tree and a RAM is a sheep; put them together to get ASHRAM, a “retreat.” https://t.co/M5s2Jk6AMi

clue_tweet_text:
Anger, confusion about one city in Canada (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“confusion”) ANGER into REGNA, then put it “about” (aboot?) the letter I (“one” in Roman numerals) to get REGINA (“city in Canada”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/Gsa4e8hs4E

clue_tweet_text:
Crews’ fabric (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: TERRY is both the first name of TV personality “Crews,” and also a “fabric.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/k3gN3RY0Ez

clue_tweet_text:
Crete’s ruin is not to be spoken of (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Ruin,” or anagram, CRETES to get “secret” (“not to be spoken of”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/elMjG1JgkG

clue_tweet_text:
Fish with hiding place where plants grow (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: GARDEN (“where plants grow”) is GAR (a type of “fish”) plus DEN (“hiding place”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/h6ccxRbqlz

clue_tweet_text:
Message hidden in lazy rock variety (11)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Put IM (“message”) in SEDENTARY (“lazy”) to get SEDIMENTARY (“rock variety”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/2pnP1bnzmF

clue_tweet_text:
Open actual rotten melon (10) 

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“rotten”) OPEN ACTUAL to get CANTALOUPE (“melon”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/dSohTovxkD

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! Now your #crypticclueaday (warning: a little specialized knowledge required):

Work with needles, keeping time for a little bit of music (8)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: The specialized knowledge here is that another name for a quarter note is a CROTCHET (“a little bit of music”), which you get from CROCHET (“work with needles”) “keeping” the letter T (“time”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/cyq3MWC5Tk

clue_tweet_text:
The ones here with American (Greek) hero (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: THESEUS (“Greek hero,” ignoring punctuation) is THESE (“the ones here”) plus US (“American”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/dw7wBzZeiu

clue_tweet_text:
Doggo, someday in disarray (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“in disarray”) SOMEDAY to get SAMOYED, a kind of “doggo.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/tM6YrkK1Lj

clue_tweet_text:
Come to a resolution about Delaware murder? (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: DE (“Delaware”) plus the suffix -CIDE (“murder”) gives you DECIDE (“come to a resolution about”). The question mark indicates the non-literal wordplay. #explanationfriday https://t.co/r8fRCBVZRs

clue_tweet_text:
Condom head found in shoe causes quite a stir (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Put C (“condom head,” or the first letter of CONDOM) into (“found in”) SANDAL (“shoe”) to get SCANDAL (“quite a stir”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/6NPTkpPi61

clue_tweet_text:
Weapons of sister with sneakers (9)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: NUNCHUCKS (“weapons”) comes from NUN (“sister”) plus CHUCKS (“sneakers,” i.e., Chuck Taylors). #explanationfriday https://t.co/ECpk5MwgGr

clue_tweet_text:
Left in place: Monument for ancient philosopher (8)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Add L (“left”) “in” PUT (“place”) to get PLUT; then add ARCH (“monument”) at the end to get PLUTARCH (“ancient philosopher”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/CHKf7yvYFB

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! And now your #crypticclueaday:

Stunning songbird eats tulip top (9)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: It’s finally #explanationfriday! In this clue, STARLING (“songbird”) “eats” the letter T (“tulip top,” or the first letter of TULIP) to make STARTLING (“stunning”). https://t.co/Hfy3Ryhdz0

clue_tweet_text:
Regularly inspire something to listen to (3)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Take every other letter (2, 4, and 6; “regularly”) of INSPIRE to get NPR (“something to listen to”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/JOhJGLQCYN

clue_tweet_text:
Repartee is popular amid terrible time (8)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: This time “terrible” isn’t an anagram indicator: it’s just defining BAD. A “terrible time” is a BAD AGE; add IN (“popular”) in the middle to get BADINAGE (“repartee”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/0UQoCX41vo

clue_tweet_text:
That lady will fire heavy projectiles (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “That lady will” is SHE’LL, which without the apostrophe is SHELL (“fire heavy projectiles”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/63y6nWqWpL

clue_tweet_text:
Switch first and third of Spanish artist’s exercise (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Take GOYA (“Spanish artist”) and “switch [the] first and third [letters]” to get YOGA (“exercise”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/L59hTbADUq

clue_tweet_text:
Inspired by a typo, as so many cryptic clues are, here's a bonus #crypticclueaday, Crossword Twitter edition:

Lacking in money, getting nothing, becoming a great constructor (6)
explanation_tweet_text: BROOKE @xandraladee is the “great constructor” you get from BROKE (“lacking money”) “receiving” the letter O (“nothing,” in which O is used to represent zero). #explanationfriday https://t.co/M6bERrDUwl

clue_tweet_text:
Newsworthy winner gave daring arrangement (10)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“arrangement”) GAVE DARING to get VINGEGAARD, a “newsworthy winner” (of the Tour de France, that is). #explanationfriday https://t.co/Jx4ycv2jcy

clue_tweet_text:
Half of very nice film festival location (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: VENICE is the “film festival location” you get from VE (“half of very,” or the first half of VERY) plus NICE (given directly in the clue). #explanationfriday https://t.co/AQNqila906

clue_tweet_text:
Hope you enjoyed #explanationfriday! Now for #crypticclueaday:

A little bit—small—making a difference (10)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: It’s #explanationfriday! This is just a charade: S (“small”) plus MATTERING (“making a difference”) makes SMATTERING (“a little bit”). https://t.co/f8XNNY8sb6

clue_tweet_text:
With that guy’s essential brown sauce? (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: The question mark indicates a non-literal definition (“brown sauce?”) for WHISKEY, which is W (“with”) plus HIS (“that guy’s”) plus KEY (“essential”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/8v4e2HhjjO

clue_tweet_text:
Patricia and Ronald meet up for tequila (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Phew, this one was easier! PAT plus RON (“Patricia and Ronald”) equals PATRON, a brand of “tequila.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/CAxPevhelT

clue_tweet_text:
Centaur, or chimerical teller of tales (9)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“chimerical”) CENTAUR OR to get RACONTEUR, a “teller of tales.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/EMN5yidQTu

clue_tweet_text:
Debussy’s “Scratched” on the radio (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: CLAUDE (“Debussy”) is a homophone (“on the radio”) of CLAWED (“Scratched”). The placement of “on the radio” indicates which word is the def and which is the homophone. #explanationfriday https://t.co/e3DxfzB00s

clue_tweet_text:
Use a spade on small, humble dwelling (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Oops, guess I used “small” the same way twice in one week: S (“small”) plus HOVEL (“humble dwelling”) makes SHOVEL (“use a spade on”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/4bRY3EgHhL

clue_tweet_text:
Easy job is awfully nice, sure (8)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“awfully”) NICE SURE to get SINECURE (“easy job”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/s3CJdRtDWM

clue_tweet_text:
Another #explanationfriday is in the books! Now for your #crypticclueaday:

Four entering sexual public revelry (8)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Phew! It’s #explanationfriday! Some tough clues this week. In this one, IV (“four” in Roman numerals) “enters” CARNAL (“sexual”) to produce CARNIVAL (“public revelry”). https://t.co/sxTHv8hQrN

clue_tweet_text:
Prussian noble’s shitty car (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: This is a double definition: JUNKER is both a “Prussian noble” and a “shitty car.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/6YQa2EkDrF

clue_tweet_text:
To a Spaniard, my anger is an illusion (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: MIRAGE is “an illusion” made from MI (“to a Spaniard, my,” or “my” in Spanish) plus RAGE (“anger”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/DasWCeuogf

clue_tweet_text:
Booze recipe from the Reverend’s party factory (4,4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: I think the definition is the hard part here: MASH BILL is a “booze recipe” (it’s the ratio of grain types that go into a beer or whiskey), and it comes from spoonerizing (“the Reverend’s) BASH MILL (“party factory”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/KmixDJVlZ3

clue_tweet_text:
Transience changed fruits (10)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“changed”) TRANSIENCE to get NECTARINES (“fruits”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/tn4eOYhlab

clue_tweet_text:
French insolence, I see (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: GALLIC (“French”) comes from GALL (“insolence”) plus I C (“I see”—think text message abbreviations). #explanationfriday https://t.co/HYkWvPDXyt

clue_tweet_text:
Alien guy from Chicago and so on (2,6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: ET CETERA (“and so on”) is ET (“alien”) plus (Peter) CETERA, a “guy from Chicago” (the band). #explanationfriday https://t.co/SGJ4iEN5zY

clue_tweet_text:
Bonus #crypticclueaday, Crossword Twitter edition (I realize I have clued this person recently, but couldn’t resist):

Ask for identification from popular cruciverbalist (6)

Like if you’ve got it and/or ARE it.
explanation_tweet_text: CARD (“ask for identification from”) plus IN (“popular”) produces “cruciverbalist” (Nate) CARDIN. Just can’t stop cluing @naytnaytnayt! #explanationfriday https://t.co/m3qGdHgPmD

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! Now for #crypticclueaday:

Clog giant container of extension (6)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: #explanationfriday has arrived! In this hidden-word clue, LOGGIA is the (architectural) “extension”) “contained” in “cLOG GIAnt.” https://t.co/o7TygX4qk7

clue_tweet_text:
Stirred rum becomes unmanageable (10)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Stir,” or anagram, RUM BECOMES to get CUMBERSOME (“unmanageable”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/b68cK4ozBW

clue_tweet_text:
Feel sorry about wading bird subreddit? (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Subreddits are of the form “r/name,” so R/EGRET (“wading bird subreddit?”) is REGRET (“feel sorry about”). The question mark indicates the not-quite-literal wordplay. #explanationfriday https://t.co/3OT1Iw5xA6

clue_tweet_text:
Variety is essential to Katy Perry (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: TYPE is the “variety” “essential to,” or hidden in, “kaTY PErry.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/xfljVXkyTK

clue_tweet_text:
Sing the French song (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: SINGLE is the “song” you get from SING (given in the clue) plus LE (“the French,” or “the” in French). #explanationfriday https://t.co/WeUGUXJMME

clue_tweet_text:
Relief occurs in confusion (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“in confusion”) OCCURS to get SUCCOR (“relief”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/UCyc8NCmvS

clue_tweet_text:
Note belonging to me spells disaster (6) 

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: FA (a musical “note”) plus MINE (“belonging to me”) “spells” FAMINE, a “disaster.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/REYANJxbQE

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! And now your #crypticclueaday:

Union member trialist gathers in the morning (8) 

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Welcome to #explanationfriday! TEAMSTER (“union member”) is TESTER (“trialist”) “gathering” AM, or “in the morning.” https://t.co/LFbEjYHW0K

clue_tweet_text:
Phosphorus with every fruit (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Easier one: P (the elemental symbol of “phosphorus”) “with” EACH (“every”) makes PEACH, a “fruit.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/QW5wuzgYzP

clue_tweet_text:
Math practitioner’s season? (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: SUMMER is both a “math practitioner” (in the sense of someone who’s doing sums) and a “season.” The question mark indicates the non-literal nature of one of the definitions. #explanationfriday https://t.co/SOJh2qSdJF

clue_tweet_text:
Double barrier: a city in Washington (5,5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: WALL (“barrier”) plus A (given in the clue) is WALLA. “Double” that to get WALLA WALLA (“city in Washington”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/SzqPt3HmGs

clue_tweet_text:
Cuddly pet’s pot (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: In this double definition, KITTY is both a “cuddly pet” and the “pot” in a poker game. #explanationfriday https://t.co/f43SvCdVo0

clue_tweet_text:
Agitate bitter oil to find fossil (9)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Agitate,” or anagram, BITTER OIL to find TRILOBITE, a “fossil.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/jakfAURdfq

clue_tweet_text:
Resist rock band (7,6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: In this unusual reverse anagram, TWISTED SISTER is the “rock band.” The word RESIST in the clue is an anagram of SISTER, so it’s a “twisted SISTER.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/MCtcN8KIhk

clue_tweet_text:
Hope #explanationfriday was helpful! Now for your #crypticclueaday:

Cart contains all the makings of waterfall (8)
 
Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: We made it! It’s #explanationfriday! In this letter bank clue, CART “contains all the makings of,” or has all the letters used in, CATARACT (“waterfall”). https://t.co/XdjZCdErsY

clue_tweet_text:
Gym class with purple garment style (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Fashion! PEPLUM is the “garment style” you get from PE (“gym class”) plus PLUM (“purple”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/FHgqRZJNAK https://t.co/xl9cBWm9GC

clue_tweet_text:
It’s a tipsy #crypticclueaday:

Bathes in stirred alcoholic drink (8)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Stir,” or anagram, BATHES IN, to get ABSINTHE, an “alcoholic drink.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/ZJ6flFbRK0

clue_tweet_text:
Reinforcement of kidnapper’s demand coming after time (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: TRANSOM is the “reinforcement” you get from RANSOM (“kidnapper’s demand”) “coming after” the letter T (an abbreviation for “time”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/CG7igaYQ3h

clue_tweet_text:
Broadcast legends in possession of fancy residence (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Surprise! “Broadcast” doesn’t indicate a homophone here: it’s part of a hidden-word phrase. “broadCAST LEgends” is “in possession of” the word CASTLE, a “fancy residence.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/Be8gJys7ex

clue_tweet_text:
Reign of gruesome alien (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“gruesome”) REIGN OF to get FOREIGN (“alien”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/ke2OtqXCue

clue_tweet_text:
Keep at it, fool (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: In this double definition, GO ON (“keep at it”) makes GOON (“fool”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/OMniTQRY1a

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! Now your #crypticclueaday:

German mom’s grumble (6)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Thank goodness it’s #explanationfriday! In this double definition, MUTTER is the German word for “mother” (“German mom”) as well as a synonym for “grumble.” https://t.co/GuIkOoJ55r

clue_tweet_text:
That pop music legend, Maggie from the UK (8)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: THAT (given in the clue) plus CHER (“pop music legend”) makes THATCHER (“Maggie from the UK”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/FRWCIuYRNn

clue_tweet_text:
Company spread something you see at Comic-Con (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: COSPLAY (“something you see at Comic-Con”) is CO (an abbreviation for “company”) plus SPLAY (“spread”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/g6XAj2Ls8f

clue_tweet_text:
Local testosterone injected into innocent (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Inject” the letter T (“testosterone”) into NAIVE (“innocent”) to get NATIVE (“local”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/Ljg9nePgl4

clue_tweet_text:
Symphony encompasses the first Madonna album (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Tough one! EROICA, a “symphony,” “encompasses” the letter T (“the first,” or the first letter of “the”) to give you EROTICA, a “Madonna album.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/6vHYwIJuLY

clue_tweet_text:
Nonconformists insult big men in speech (10) 

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: DISSENTERS (“nonconformists”) is a homophone (“in speech”) of DIS CENTERS (“insult big men,” in the NBA sense of “big men”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/DNpGBaaEzD

clue_tweet_text:
Sounds like UK (English) composer (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: (Benjamin) BRITTEN is the “English composer” whose name is a homophone (“sounds like”) of BRITAIN (“UK”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/6SK3niYiuX

clue_tweet_text:
Hope you enjoyed #explanationfriday! Now your #crypticclueaday:

Movie general starts to lead everyone in alliance (4)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: What a week! It’s #explanationfriday. In this acrostic clue, “movie general” LEIA is formed from the “starts to,” or first letters of, the last four words in the clue. https://t.co/WUFSUWq7Ee

clue_tweet_text:
Messy place with the French fashions (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: STYLES (“fashions”) is STY (“messy place”) plus LES (“the French,” or a way to say “the” in French). #explanationfriday https://t.co/Jb4LlPrmBw

clue_tweet_text:
Machiavellian villain clutches heavy equipment (5) 

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: In this hidden-word clue, the phrase “machiavelliAN VILlain” “clutches” the answer, ANVIL (“heavy equipment”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/bIfrDH1LVd

clue_tweet_text:
Doggo eats in cradle (8)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: When BASSET, a type of “doggo,” “eats” the word IN (given directly in the clue, so it’s not an extraneous connector word), you get BASSINET, a “cradle.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/72kU18RV84

clue_tweet_text:
Shall lose the opening entrance (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Lose the opening,” or remove the first letter, of the word SHALL (given directly in the clue) to get HALL (“entrance”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/ZYFDfSY2LF

clue_tweet_text:
Amsterdam Avenue constituents include expert (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Another hidden-word clue: the answer, MAVEN, is in the middle of (“constituents include”) the phrase “AmsterdaM AVENue.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/dGDUwdrLvv

clue_tweet_text:
Sing and laugh, make a beer (6) 

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: SING (given in the clue) and HA (“laugh”) “make a beer”: SINGHA. #explanationfriday https://t.co/gTfc3G9VXf

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! Now for your #crypticclueaday (warning! Some specialized knowledge required):

Like a quiet period composer? (5)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Time for some explanations! French “composer” (Jean-Baptiste) LULLY’s name could be said to be “like a quiet period” (LULL-Y). The question mark indicates the non-literal nature of the wordplay. #explanationfriday https://t.co/0orivDM9oi

clue_tweet_text:
Observing nothing, having no heart (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: NOTING (“observing”) is NOTHING (given in the clue) without its middle letter (“having no heart”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/6l0GIND5s4

clue_tweet_text:
Type of protest takes on Yemen’s first form of government (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Enumeration should’ve been (8) for MONARCHY, a “form of government” you get when MARCH (“type of protest”) “takes,” or contains, the word ON, with Y (“Yemen’s first”) at the end. #explanationfriday https://t.co/KGHRd3XMOE

clue_tweet_text:
Pitches a bizarre imitation (8) 

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: A PASTICHE is an “imitation” that comes from anagramming (“bizarre”) PITCHES A. #explanationfriday https://t.co/wl8gfcSfih

clue_tweet_text:
That man, at that time, captured one unbeliever (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: HE THEN (“that man” and “at that time” respectively) “captures” the letter A (“one,” in the indefinite article sense) to make HEATHEN (“unbeliever”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/4IkBb4ih72

clue_tweet_text:
Hi, open broken device (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: IPHONE is the “device” you get from “breaking,” or anagramming, HI OPEN. #explanationfriday https://t.co/RIj5iu156h

clue_tweet_text:
You quitting a company? That’s a cliche (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: When the letter U (“you”) “quits,” or leaves, TROUPE (“a company”), you get TROPE (“That’s a cliche”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/SHRrUfDapV

clue_tweet_text:
No more #explanationfriday! Now your #crypticclueaday:

Bird on fire beside ocean’s head (8)

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: It’s #explanationfriday! FLAMINGO (“bird”) is FLAMING (“on fire”) plus O (“ocean’s head,” or the first letter of OCEAN). https://t.co/LlHG94NjmJ

clue_tweet_text:
Washington deserts facilities, leaving behind fungus (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.

clue_tweet_text:
Expert loses head for flower (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Lose the head,” or remove the first letter from, MASTER (“expert”) to get ASTER, a “flower.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/51U5MWqGkH

clue_tweet_text:
Margaret temporarily provided Shabbat meal (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: CHO (“Margaret,” i.e., comic Margaret CHO) plus LENT (“temporarily provided”) gives you CHOLENT, a “Shabbat meal.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/sKIAIXa4RU

clue_tweet_text:
Melanie, nearly failing in card game action (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.

clue_tweet_text:
Composer lurks in Carousel Gardens (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it. https://t.co/bHi9CfVLp8

clue_tweet_text:
Song having less feeling (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! Now, a #crypticclueaday:

Spanish-English fireplaces (6)

 Like if you’ve got it.

clue_tweet_text:
Reverend’s method Newman used to make content restriction (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.

clue_tweet_text:
Gamer got bad loan (8)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“bad”) GAMER GOT to get MORTGAGE (“loan”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/oowRjYQuEO

clue_tweet_text:
Musical assistant took a trip on ecstasy, it’s said (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Tough one! ROADIE (“musical assistant”) is a homophone (“it’s said”) of RODE E (“took a trip on” = ROAD; “ecstasy” = E). #explanationfriday https://t.co/vGwPnQP7m2

clue_tweet_text:
Drink made entirely from components of spiral (12)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: In this letter bank, SPIRAL contains all of the unique letters in (“made entirely from components of”) SARSAPARILLA (“drink”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/yBp4zmH3rq

clue_tweet_text:
Imagine, in a whirlwind, losing one puzzle (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: Anagram (“in a whirlwind”) IMAGINE and take away one of the Is (“losing one,” as in Roman numeral I) to get ENIGMA (“puzzle”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/R82RKyEERT

clue_tweet_text:
Child and adult actress (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Actress” Nicole KIDMAN’s name is made by adding KID (“child”) and MAN (“adult”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/RCSCUuY63g

clue_tweet_text:
That’s it for #explanationfriday! Now for #crypticclueaday:

Quiet-quitting clergyperson causes crime (5) 

Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: We made it to #explanationfriday! ARSON is the “crime” “caused” when P (“quiet,” as in the musical marking) “quits,” or leaves, PARSON (“clergyperson”). https://t.co/qcu0a5ZKdy

clue_tweet_text:
Bonus #crypticclueaday, super-timely edition:

Sounds like horses' team that's very exciting rn (8)

Like if you've got it.
explanation_tweet_text: It’s the PHILLIES (“team that’s very exciting rn”), of course! They “sound like” FILLIES, or “horses.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/7b7kh5x8xt

clue_tweet_text:
Philadelphia school with impressive and popular advocate for neurodiverse thinkers (6,7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: The “advocate for neurodiverse thinkers” is TEMPLE GRANDIN. TEMPLE is a “Philadelphia school”; GRAND is “impressive”; IN is “popular.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/lODeN35Y0i

clue_tweet_text:
A thousand got together, surrounding our old magazine (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: G = “a thousand” and MET = “got together.” When they “surround” OUR (given directly in the clue), you get the “old magazine” GOURMET. #explanationfriday https://t.co/CuxvqKOJ7b

clue_tweet_text:
Cool, average guys on Second and Third (5)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Cool” is a fall-appropriate definition of CRISP, which you get from C (“average,” as in the letter grade) plus RISP (the baseball abbreviation for “runners in scoring position,” or “guys on second and third”). Ignore the deceptive capital letters! #explanationfriday https://t.co/DaL32i3OW9

clue_tweet_text:
Assistant of knight and yours truly (4)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: SIRI is the “assistant” you get from SIR (“knight”) plus I (“yours truly”). #explanationfriday https://t.co/hG0JgLFBu4

clue_tweet_text:
Dueled agitated fool (6)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: “Agitate,” or anagram, the word DUELED to get DELUDE (“fool” in its verb sense). #explanationfriday https://t.co/9vN8JPI46J

clue_tweet_text:
Greek island sausages (7)

#crypticclueaday Like if you’ve got it.
explanation_tweet_text: In this double definition, SALAMIS is both a “Greek island” and “sausages.” #explanationfriday https://t.co/pCogilhIBh
